p.verse: 1The words of Jeremiah, the son of Hilkiah, one of the priests living in Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin.
2The word of the Lord came to him in the thirteenth year of the reign of Josiah son of Amon, king of Judah.

3It also came throughout the days of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah, until the fifth month of the eleventh year of Zedekiah son of Josiah, king of Judah, when the people of Jerusalem went into exile.
4The word of the Lord came to me:

poem.verse: 5I chose you before I formed you in the womb;

poetryblock.poem: I set you apart before you were born.
I appointed you a prophet to the nations.

p.verse: 6But I protested, ‘Oh no, Lord God! Look, I don’t know how to speak since I am only a youth.’
7Then the Lord said to me:

poetryblock.poem: Do not say, ‘I am only a youth,’
for you will go to everyone I send you to
and speak whatever I tell you.

poem.verse: 8Do not be afraid of anyone,

poetryblock.poem: for I will be with you to rescue you.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

p.verse: 9Then the Lord reached out his hand, touched my mouth, and told me:

poetryblock.poem: I have now filled your mouth with my words.

poem.verse: 10See, I have appointed you today

poetryblock.poem: over nations and kingdoms
to uproot and tear down,
to destroy and demolish,
to build and plant.

p.verse: 11Then the word of the Lord came to me, asking, ‘What do you see, Jeremiah? ’

chapter.p: I replied, ‘I see a branch of an almond tree.’

p.verse: 12The Lord said to me, ‘You have seen correctly, for I watch over my word to accomplish it.’
13Again the word of the Lord came to me asking, ‘What do you see? ’

chapter.p: And I replied, ‘I see a boiling pot, its lip tilted from the north to the south.’

p.verse: 14Then the Lord said to me, ‘Disaster will be poured out from the north on all who live in the land.
15Indeed, I am about to summon all the clans and kingdoms of the north.’

poetryblock.poem: They will come, and each king will set up his throne
at the entrance to Jerusalem’s gates.
They will attack all her surrounding walls
and all the other cities of Judah.

p.verse: 16‘I will pronounce my judgements against them for all the evil they did when they abandoned me to burn incense to other gods and to worship the works of their own hands.
17‘Now, get ready. Stand up and tell them everything that I command you. Do not be intimidated by them or I will cause you to cower before them.
18Today, I am the one who has made you a fortified city, an iron pillar, and bronze walls against the whole land ​– ​against the kings of Judah, its officials, its priests, and the population.
19They will fight against you but never prevail over you, since I am with you to rescue you.’
1The word of the Lord came to me:
2‘Go and announce directly to Jerusalem that this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I remember the loyalty of your youth,
your love as a bride –
how you followed me in the wilderness,
in a land not sown.

poem.verse: 3Israel was holy to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: the firstfruits of his harvest.
All who ate of it found themselves guilty;
disaster came on them.’
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 4Hear the word of the Lord, house of Jacob

poetryblock.poem: and all families of the house of Israel.

poem.verse: 5This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: What fault did your ancestors find in me
that they went so far from me,
followed worthless idols,
and became worthless themselves?

poem.verse: 6They stopped asking, ‘Where is the Lord

poetryblock.poem: who brought us from the land of Egypt,
who led us through the wilderness,
through a land of deserts and ravines,
through a land of drought and darkness,
a land no one travelled through
and where no one lived? ’

poem.verse: 7I brought you to a fertile land

poetryblock.poem: to eat its fruit and bounty,
but after you entered, you defiled my land;
you made my inheritance detestable.

poem.verse: 8The priests stopped asking, ‘Where is the Lord? ’

poetryblock.poem: The experts in the law no longer knew me,
and the rulers rebelled against me.
The prophets prophesied by Baal
and followed useless idols.

poem.verse: 9Therefore, I will bring a case against you again.

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
I will bring a case against your children’s children.

poem.verse: 10Cross over to the coasts of Cyprus and take a look.

poetryblock.poem: Send someone to Kedar and consider carefully;
see if there has ever been anything like this:

poem.verse: 11Has a nation ever exchanged its gods?

poetryblock.poem: (But they were not gods!)
Yet my people have exchanged their Glory
for useless idols.

poem.verse: 12Be appalled at this, heavens;

poetryblock.poem: be shocked and utterly desolated!
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 13For my people have committed a double evil:

poetryblock.poem: They have abandoned me,
the fountain of living water,
and dug cisterns for themselves ​– ​
cracked cisterns that cannot hold water.

poem.verse: 14Is Israel a slave?

poetryblock.poem: Was he born into slavery?
Why else has he become a prey?

poem.verse: 15The young lions have roared at him;

poetryblock.poem: they have roared loudly.
They have laid waste his land.
His cities are in ruins, without inhabitants.

poem.verse: 16The men of Memphis and Tahpanhes

poetryblock.poem: have also broken your skull.

poem.verse: 17Have you not brought this on yourself

poetryblock.poem: by abandoning the Lord your God
while he was leading you along the way?

poem.verse: 18Now what will you gain

poetryblock.poem: by travelling along the way to Egypt
to drink the water of the Nile?
What will you gain
by travelling along the way to Assyria
to drink the water of the Euphrates?

poem.verse: 19Your own evil will discipline you;

poetryblock.poem: your own apostasies will reprimand you.
Recognise how evil and bitter it is
for you to abandon the Lord your God
and to have no fear of me.
This is the declaration
of the Lord God of Armies.

poem.verse: 20For long ago I broke your yoke;

poetryblock.poem: I tore off your chains.
You insisted, ‘I will not serve! ’
On every high hill
and under every green tree
you lay down like a prostitute.

poem.verse: 21I planted you, a choice vine

poetryblock.poem: from the very best seed.
How then could you turn into
a degenerate, foreign vine?

poem.verse: 22Even if you wash with lye

poetryblock.poem: and use a great amount of bleach,
the stain of your iniquity is still in front of me.
This is the Lord God’s declaration.

poem.verse: 23How can you protest, ‘I am not defiled;

poetryblock.poem: I have not followed the Baals’?
Look at your behaviour in the valley;
acknowledge what you have done.
You are a swift young camel
twisting and turning on her way,

poem.verse: 24a wild donkey at home in the wilderness.

poetryblock.poem: She sniffs the wind in the heat of her desire.
Who can control her passion?
All who look for her will not become weary;
they will find her in her mating season.

poem.verse: 25Keep your feet from going bare

poetryblock.poem: and your throat from thirst.
But you say, ‘It’s hopeless;
I love strangers,
and I will continue to follow them.’

poem.verse: 26Like the shame of a thief when he is caught,

poetryblock.poem: so the house of Israel has been put to shame.
They, their kings, their officials,
their priests, and their prophets

poem.verse: 27say to a tree, ‘You are my father,’

poetryblock.poem: and to a stone, ‘You gave birth to me.’
For they have turned their back to me
and not their face,
yet in their time of disaster they beg,
‘Rise up and save us! ’

poem.verse: 28But where are your gods you made for yourself?

poetryblock.poem: Let them rise up and save you
in your time of disaster if they can,
for your gods are as numerous as your cities, Judah.

poem.verse: 29Why do you bring a case against me?

poetryblock.poem: All of you have rebelled against me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 30I have struck down your children in vain;

poetryblock.poem: they would not accept discipline.
Your own sword has devoured your prophets
like a ravaging lion.

poem.verse: 31Evil generation,

poetryblock.poem: pay attention to the word of the Lord!
Have I been a wilderness to Israel
or a land of dense darkness?
Why do my people claim,
‘We will go where we want;
we will no longer come to you’?

poem.verse: 32Can a young woman forget her jewellery

poetryblock.poem: or a bride her wedding sash?
Yet my people have forgotten me
for countless days.

poem.verse: 33How skilfully you pursue love;

poetryblock.poem: you also teach evil women your ways.

poem.verse: 34Moreover, your skirts are stained

poetryblock.poem: with the blood of the innocent poor.
You did not catch them breaking and entering.
But in spite of all these things

poem.verse: 35you claim, ‘I am innocent.

poetryblock.poem: His anger is sure to turn away from me.’
But I will certainly judge you
because you have said, ‘I have not sinned.’

poem.verse: 36How unstable you are,

poetryblock.poem: constantly changing your ways!
You will be put to shame by Egypt
just as you were put to shame by Assyria.

poem.verse: 37Moreover, you will be led out from here

poetryblock.poem: with your hands on your head
since the Lord has rejected those you trust;
you will not succeed even with their help.

poem.verse: 1If a man divorces his wife

poetryblock.poem: and she leaves him to marry another,
can he ever return to her?
Wouldn’t such a land become totally defiled?
But you!
You have prostituted yourself with many partners –
can you return to me?
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 2Look to the barren heights and see.

poetryblock.poem: Where have you not been immoral?
You sat waiting for them beside the roads
like a nomad in the desert.
You have defiled the land
with your prostitution and wickedness.

poem.verse: 3This is why the showers haven’t come –

poetryblock.poem: why there has been no spring rain.
You have the brazen look of a prostitute
and refuse to be ashamed.

poem.verse: 4Haven’t you recently called to me, ‘My Father!

poetryblock.poem: You were my friend in my youth.

poem.verse: 5Will he bear a grudge for ever?

poetryblock.poem: Will he be endlessly infuriated? ’
This is what you have said,
but you have done the evil things
you are capable of.

p.verse: 6In the days of King Josiah the Lord asked me, ‘Have you seen what unfaithful Israel has done? She has ascended every high hill and gone under every green tree to prostitute herself there.
7I thought, “After she has done all these things, she will return to me.” But she didn’t return, and her treacherous sister Judah saw it.

8I observed that it was because unfaithful Israel had committed adultery that I had sent her away and had given her a certificate of divorce. Nevertheless, her treacherous sister Judah was not afraid but also went and prostituted herself.
9Indifferent to her prostitution, she defiled the land and committed adultery with stones and trees.
10Yet in spite of all this, her treacherous sister Judah didn’t return to me with all her heart ​– ​only in pretence.’
11The Lord announced to me, ‘Unfaithful Israel has shown herself more righteous than treacherous Judah.
12Go, proclaim these words to the north, and say,

poetryblock.poem: “Return, unfaithful Israel.
This is the Lord’s declaration.
I will not look on you with anger,
for I am unfailing in my love.
This is the Lord’s declaration.
I will not be angry for ever.

poem.verse: 13Only acknowledge your guilt –

poetryblock.poem: you have rebelled against the Lord your God.
You have scattered your favours to strangers
under every green tree
and have not obeyed me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

p.verse: 14‘ “Return, you faithless children ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​for I am your master, and I will take you, one from a city and two from a family, and I will bring you to Zion.
15I will give you shepherds who are loyal to me, and they will shepherd you with knowledge and skill.

16When you multiply and increase in the land, in those days ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​no one will say again, ‘The ark of the Lord’s covenant.’ It will never come to mind, and no one will remember or miss it. Another one will not be made.

17At that time Jerusalem will be called The Lord’s Throne, and all the nations will be gathered to it, to the name of the Lord in Jerusalem. They will cease to follow the stubbornness of their evil hearts.
18In those days the house of Judah will join with the house of Israel, and they will come together from the land of the north to the land I have given your ancestors to inherit.” ’

poem.verse: 19I thought, ‘How I long to make you my sons

poetryblock.poem: and give you a desirable land,
the most beautiful inheritance of all the nations.’
I thought, ‘You will call me “My Father”
and never turn away from me.’

poem.verse: 20However, as a woman may betray her lover,

poetryblock.poem: so you have betrayed me, house of Israel.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 21A sound is heard on the barren heights:

poetryblock.poem: the children of Israel weeping and begging for mercy,
for they have perverted their way;
they have forgotten the Lord their God.

poem.verse: 22Return, you faithless children.

poetryblock.poem: I will heal your unfaithfulness.
‘Here we are, coming to you,
for you are the Lord our God.

poem.verse: 23Surely, falsehood comes from the hills,

poetryblock.poem: commotion from the mountains,
but the salvation of Israel
is only in the Lord our God.

poem.verse: 24From the time of our youth

poetryblock.poem: the shameful one has consumed
what our ancestors have worked for –
their flocks and their herds,
their sons and their daughters.

poem.verse: 25Let us lie down in our shame;

poetryblock.poem: let our disgrace cover us.
We have sinned against the Lord our God,
both we and our ancestors,
from the time of our youth even to this day.
We have not obeyed the Lord our God.’

poem.verse: 1If you return, Israel –

poetryblock.poem: this is the Lord’s declaration –
you will return to me,
if you remove your abhorrent idols
from my presence
and do not waver,

poem.verse: 2then you can swear, ‘As the Lord lives,’

poetryblock.poem: in truth, justice, and righteousness,
and then the nations will be blessed by him
and will boast in him.

p.verse: 3For this is what the Lord says to the men of Judah and Jerusalem:

poetryblock.poem: Break up the unploughed ground;
do not sow among the thorns.

poem.verse: 4Circumcise yourselves to the Lord;

poetryblock.poem: remove the foreskin of your hearts,
men of Judah and residents of Jerusalem.
Otherwise, my wrath will break out like fire
and burn with no one to extinguish it
because of your evil deeds.

p.verse: 5Declare in Judah, proclaim in Jerusalem, and say,

poetryblock.poem: Blow the ram’s horn throughout the land.
Cry out loudly and say,
‘Assemble yourselves,
and let’s flee to the fortified cities.’

poem.verse: 6Lift up a signal flag towards Zion.

poetryblock.poem: Run for cover! Don’t stand still!
For I am bringing disaster from the north –
a crushing blow.

poem.verse: 7A lion has gone up from his thicket;

poetryblock.poem: a destroyer of nations has set out.
He has left his lair
to make your land a waste.
Your cities will be reduced to uninhabited ruins.

poem.verse: 8Because of this, put on sackcloth;

poetryblock.poem: mourn and wail,
for the Lord’s burning anger
has not turned away from us.

p.verse: 9‘On that day’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘the king and the officials will lose their courage. The priests will tremble in fear, and the prophets will be scared speechless.’
10I said, ‘Oh no, Lord God, you have certainly deceived this people and Jerusalem, by announcing, “You will have peace,” while a sword is at our throats.’
11‘At that time it will be said to this people and to Jerusalem, “A searing wind blows from the barren heights in the wilderness on the way to my dear people. It comes not to winnow or to sift;
12a wind too strong for this comes at my call. Now I will also pronounce judgements against them.” ’

poem.verse: 13Look, he advances like clouds;

poetryblock.poem: his chariots are like a storm.
His horses are swifter than eagles.
Woe to us, for we are ruined!

poem.verse: 14Wash the evil from your heart, Jerusalem,

poetryblock.poem: so that you will be delivered.
How long will you harbour
malicious thoughts?

poem.verse: 15For a voice announces from Dan,

poetryblock.poem: proclaiming malice from Mount Ephraim.

poem.verse: 16Warn the nations: Look!

poetryblock.poem: Proclaim to Jerusalem:
Those who besiege are coming
from a distant land;
they raise their voices
against the cities of Judah.

poem.verse: 17They have her surrounded

poetryblock.poem: like those who guard a field,
because she has rebelled against me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 18Your way and your actions

poetryblock.poem: have brought this on you.
This is your punishment. It is very bitter,
because it has reached your heart!

poem.verse: 19My anguish, my anguish! I writhe in agony!

poetryblock.poem: Oh, the pain in my heart!
My heart pounds;
I cannot be silent.
For you, my soul,
have heard the sound of the ram’s horn –
the shout of battle.

poem.verse: 20Disaster after disaster is reported

poetryblock.poem: because the whole land is destroyed.
Suddenly my tents are destroyed,
my tent curtains, in a moment.

poem.verse: 21How long must I see the signal flag

poetryblock.poem: and hear the sound of the ram’s horn?

poem.verse: 22‘For my people are fools;

poetryblock.poem: they do not know me.
They are foolish children,
without understanding.
They are skilled in doing what is evil,
but they do not know how to do what is good.’

poem.verse: 23I looked at the earth,

poetryblock.poem: and it was formless and empty.
I looked to the heavens,
and their light was gone.

poem.verse: 24I looked at the mountains,

poetryblock.poem: and they were quaking;
all the hills shook.

poem.verse: 25I looked, and there was no human being,

poetryblock.poem: and all the birds of the sky had fled.

poem.verse: 26I looked, and the fertile field was a wilderness.

poetryblock.poem: All its cities were torn down
because of the Lord
and his burning anger.

p.verse: 27For this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: ‘The whole land will be a desolation,
but I will not finish it off.

poem.verse: 28Because of this, the earth will mourn;

poetryblock.poem: the skies above will grow dark.
I have spoken; I have planned,
and I will not relent or turn back from it.’

poem.verse: 29Every city flees

poetryblock.poem: at the sound of the horseman and the archer.
They enter the thickets
and climb among the rocks.
Every city is abandoned;
no inhabitant is left.

poem.verse: 30And you, devastated one, what are you doing

poetryblock.poem: that you dress yourself in scarlet,
that you adorn yourself with gold jewellery,
that you enhance your eyes with makeup?
You beautify yourself for nothing.
Your lovers reject you;
they intend to take your life.

poem.verse: 31I hear a cry like a woman in labour,

poetryblock.poem: a cry of anguish like one bearing her first child.
The cry of Daughter Zion gasping for breath,
stretching out her hands:
‘Woe is me, for my life is weary
because of the murderers! ’

poem.verse: 1Roam through the streets of Jerusalem.

poetryblock.poem: Investigate;
search in her squares.
If you find one person,
any who acts justly,
who pursues faithfulness,
then I will forgive her.

poem.verse: 2When they say, ‘As the Lord lives,’

poetryblock.poem: they are swearing falsely.

poem.verse: 3Lord, don’t your eyes look for faithfulness?

poetryblock.poem: You have struck them, but they felt no pain.
You finished them off,
but they refused to accept discipline.
They made their faces harder than rock,
and they refused to return.

p.verse: 4Then I thought:

poetryblock.poem: They are just the poor;
they have been foolish.
For they don’t understand the way of the Lord,
the justice of their God.

poem.verse: 5I will go to the powerful

poetryblock.poem: and speak to them.
Surely they know the way of the Lord,
the justice of their God.
However, these also had broken the yoke
and torn off the chains.

poem.verse: 6Therefore, a lion from the forest will strike them down.

poetryblock.poem: A wolf from arid plains will ravage them.
A leopard stalks their cities.
Anyone who leaves them will be torn to pieces
because their rebellious acts are many,
their unfaithful deeds numerous.

poem.verse: 7Why should I forgive you?

poetryblock.poem: Your children have abandoned me
and sworn by those who are not gods.
I satisfied their needs, yet they committed adultery;
they gashed themselves at the prostitute’s house.

poem.verse: 8They are well-fed, eager stallions,

poetryblock.poem: each neighing after someone else’s wife.

poem.verse: 9Should I not punish them for these things?

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
Should I not avenge myself
on such a nation as this?

poem.verse: 10Go up among her vineyard terraces and destroy them,

poetryblock.poem: but do not finish them off.
Prune away her shoots,
for they do not belong to the Lord.

poem.verse: 11They, the house of Israel and the house of Judah,

poetryblock.poem: have dealt very treacherously with me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 12They have contradicted the Lord

poetryblock.poem: and insisted, ‘It won’t happen.
Harm won’t come to us;
we won’t see sword or famine.’

poem.verse: 13The prophets become only wind,

poetryblock.poem: for the Lord’s word is not in them.
This will in fact happen to them.

p.verse: 14Therefore, this is what the Lord God of Armies says:

poetryblock.poem: Because you have spoken this word,
I am going to make my words
become fire in your mouth.
These people are the wood,
and the fire will consume them.

poem.verse: 15I am about to bring a nation

poetryblock.poem: from far away against you,
house of Israel.
This is the Lord’s declaration.
It is an established nation,
an ancient nation,
a nation whose language you do not know
and whose speech you do not understand.

poem.verse: 16Their quiver is like an open grave;

poetryblock.poem: they are all warriors.

poem.verse: 17They will consume your harvest and your food.

poetryblock.poem: They will consume your sons and your daughters.
They will consume your flocks and your herds.
They will consume your vines and your fig trees.
With the sword they will destroy
your fortified cities in which you trust.

p.verse: 18‘But even in those days’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘I will not finish you off.

19When people ask, “For what offence has the Lord our God done all these things to us? ”, you will respond to them, “Just as you abandoned me and served foreign gods in your land, so will you serve strangers in a land that is not yours.”
20‘Declare this in the house of Jacob; proclaim it in Judah, saying:

poem.verse: 21Hear this,

poetryblock.poem: you foolish and senseless people.
They have eyes, but they don’t see.
They have ears, but they don’t hear.

poem.verse: 22Do you not fear me?

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
Do you not tremble before me,
the one who set the sand as the boundary of the sea,
an enduring barrier that it cannot cross?
The waves surge, but they cannot prevail.
They roar, but cannot pass over it.

poem.verse: 23But these people have stubborn and rebellious hearts.

poetryblock.poem: They have turned aside and have gone away.

poem.verse: 24They have not said to themselves,

poetryblock.poem: “Let’s fear the Lord our God,
who gives the seasonal rains, both autumn and spring,
who guarantees to us the fixed weeks of the harvest.”

poem.verse: 25Your guilty acts have diverted these things from you.

poetryblock.poem: Your sins have withheld my bounty from you,

poem.verse: 26for wicked men live among my people.

poetryblock.poem: They watch like hunters lying in wait.
They set a trap;
they catch men.

poem.verse: 27Like a cage full of birds,

poetryblock.poem: so their houses are full of deceit.
Therefore they have grown powerful and rich.

poem.verse: 28They have become fat and sleek.

poetryblock.poem: They have also excelled in evil matters.
They have not taken up cases,
such as the case of the fatherless, so they might prosper,
and they have not defended the rights of the needy.

poem.verse: 29Should I not punish them for these things?

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
Should I not avenge myself
on such a nation as this?

poem.verse: 30‘An appalling, horrible thing

poetryblock.poem: has taken place in the land.

poem.verse: 31The prophets prophesy falsely,

poetryblock.poem: and the priests rule by their own authority.
My people love it like this.
But what will you do at the end of it?

poem.verse: 1‘Run for cover

poetryblock.poem: out of Jerusalem, Benjaminites.
Sound the ram’s horn in Tekoa;
raise a smoke signal over Beth-haccherem,
for disaster threatens from the north,
even a crushing blow.

poem.verse: 2Though she is beautiful and delicate,

poetryblock.poem: I will destroy Daughter Zion.

poem.verse: 3Shepherds and their flocks will come against her;

poetryblock.poem: they will pitch their tents all around her.
Each will pasture his own portion.

poem.verse: 4Set them apart for war against her;

poetryblock.poem: rise up, let’s attack at noon.
Woe to us, for the day is passing;
the evening shadows grow long.

poem.verse: 5Rise up, let’s attack by night.

poetryblock.poem: Let’s destroy her fortresses.’

p.verse: 6For this is what the Lord of Armies says:

poetryblock.poem: Cut down the trees;
raise a siege ramp against Jerusalem.
This city must be punished.
There is nothing but oppression within her.

poem.verse: 7As a well gushes out its water,

poetryblock.poem: so she pours out her evil.
Violence and destruction resound in her.
Sickness and wounds keep coming to my attention.

poem.verse: 8Be warned, Jerusalem,

poetryblock.poem: or I will turn away from you;
I will make you a desolation,
a land without inhabitants.

p.verse: 9This is what the Lord of Armies says:

poetryblock.poem: Glean the remnant of Israel
as thoroughly as a vine.
Pass your hand once more like a grape gatherer
over the branches.

poem.verse: 10Who can I speak to and give such a warning

poetryblock.poem: that they will listen?
Look, their ear is uncircumcised,
so they cannot pay attention.
See, the word of the Lord has become contemptible to them –
they find no pleasure in it.

poem.verse: 11But I am full of the Lord’s wrath;

poetryblock.poem: I am tired of holding it back.
Pour it out on the children in the street,
on the gathering of young men as well.
For both husband and wife will be captured,
the old with the very old.

poem.verse: 12Their houses will be turned over to others,

poetryblock.poem: their fields and wives as well,
for I will stretch out my hand
against the inhabitants of the land.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 13For from the least to the greatest of them,

poetryblock.poem: everyone is making profit dishonestly.
From prophet to priest,
everyone deals falsely.

poem.verse: 14They have treated my people’s brokenness superficially,

poetryblock.poem: claiming, ‘Peace, peace,’
when there is no peace.

poem.verse: 15Were they ashamed when they acted so detestably?

poetryblock.poem: They weren’t at all ashamed.
They can no longer feel humiliation.
Therefore, they will fall among the fallen.
When I punish them, they will collapse,
says the Lord.

p.verse: 16This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Stand by the roadways and look.
Ask about the ancient paths,
‘Which is the way to what is good? ’
Then take it
and find rest for yourselves.
But they protested, ‘We won’t! ’

poem.verse: 17I appointed watchmen over you

poetryblock.poem: and said, ‘Listen for the sound of the ram’s horn.’
But they protested, ‘We won’t listen! ’

poem.verse: 18Therefore listen, you nations

poetryblock.poem: and you witnesses,
learn what the charge is against them.

poem.verse: 19Listen, earth!

poetryblock.poem: I am about to bring disaster on these people,
the fruit of their own plotting,
for they have paid no attention to my words.
They have rejected my instruction.

poem.verse: 20What use to me is frankincense from Sheba

poetryblock.poem: or sweet cane from a distant land?
Your burnt offerings are not acceptable;
your sacrifices do not please me.

poem.verse: 21Therefore, this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I am going to place stumbling blocks before these people;
fathers and sons together will stumble over them;
friends and neighbours will also perish.

chapter.head1: A Cruel Nation from the North

p.verse: 22This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Look, an army is coming from a northern land;
a great nation will be stirred up
from the remote regions of the earth.

poem.verse: 23They grasp bow and javelin.

poetryblock.poem: They are cruel and show no mercy.
Their voice roars like the sea,
and they ride on horses,
lined up like men in battle formation
against you, Daughter Zion.

poem.verse: 24We have heard about it,

poetryblock.poem: and our hands have become weak.
Distress has seized us –
pain, like a woman in labour.

poem.verse: 25Don’t go out to the fields;

poetryblock.poem: don’t walk on the road.
For the enemy has a sword;
terror is on every side.

poem.verse: 26My dear people, dress yourselves in sackcloth

poetryblock.poem: and roll in the dust.
Mourn as you would for an only son,
a bitter lament,
for suddenly the destroyer will come on us.

poem.verse: 27I have appointed you to be an assayer among my people –

poetryblock.poem: a refiner –
so that you may know and assay their way of life.

poem.verse: 28All are stubborn rebels,

poetryblock.poem: spreading slander.
They are bronze and iron;
all of them are corrupt.

poem.verse: 29The bellows blow,

poetryblock.poem: blasting the lead with fire.
The refining is completely in vain;
the evil ones are not separated out.

poem.verse: 30They are called rejected silver,

poetryblock.poem: for the Lord has rejected them.

p.verse: 1This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
2‘Stand in the gate of the house of the Lord and there call out this word: “Hear the word of the Lord, all you people of Judah who enter through these gates to worship the Lord.
3‘ “This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Correct your ways and your actions, and I will allow you to live in this place.
4Do not trust deceitful words, chanting, ‘This is the temple of the Lord, the temple of the Lord, the temple of the Lord.’
5Instead, if you really correct your ways and your actions, if you act justly towards one another,
6if you no longer oppress the resident foreigner, the fatherless, and the widow, and no longer shed innocent blood in this place or follow other gods, bringing harm on yourselves,
7I will allow you to live in this place, the land I gave to your ancestors long ago and for ever.
8But look, you keep trusting in deceitful words that cannot help.
9‘ “Do you steal, murder, commit adultery, swear falsely, burn incense to Baal, and follow other gods that you have not known?
10Then do you come and stand before me in this house that bears my name and say, ‘We are rescued, so we can continue doing all these detestable acts’?
11Has this house, which bears my name, become a den of robbers in your view? Yes, I too have seen it.
12‘ “But return to my place that was at Shiloh, where I made my name dwell at first. See what I did to it because of the evil of my people Israel.

13Now, because you have done all these things ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​and because I have spoken to you time and time again but you wouldn’t listen, and I have called to you, but you wouldn’t answer,
14what I did to Shiloh I will do to the house that bears my name, the house in which you trust, the place that I gave you and your ancestors.
15I will banish you from my presence, just as I banished all of your brothers, all the descendants of Ephraim.”
16‘As for you, do not pray for these people. Do not offer a cry or a prayer on their behalf, and do not beg me, for I will not listen to you.
17Don’t you see how they behave in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?
18The sons gather wood, the fathers light the fire, and the women knead dough to make cakes for the queen of heaven, and they pour out drink offerings to other gods so that they provoke me to anger.
19But are they really provoking me? ’ This is the Lord’s declaration. ‘Isn’t it they themselves being provoked to disgrace? ’

20Therefore, this is what the Lord God says: ‘Look, my anger ​– ​my burning wrath ​– ​is about to be poured out on this place, on people and animals, on the tree of the field, and on the produce of the land. My wrath will burn and not be quenched.’
21This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Add your burnt offerings to your other sacrifices, and eat the meat yourselves,
22for when I brought your ancestors out of the land of Egypt, I did not speak with them or command them concerning burnt offering and sacrifice.
23However, I did give them this command: “Obey me, and then I will be your God, and you will be my people. Follow every way I command you so that it may go well with you.”
24Yet they didn’t listen or pay attention, but followed their own advice and their own stubborn, evil heart. They went backwards and not forwards.
25Since the day your ancestors came out of the land of Egypt until today, I have sent all my servants the prophets to you time and time again.
26However, my people wouldn’t listen to me or pay attention but became obstinate; they did more evil than their ancestors.
27‘When you speak all these things to them, they will not listen to you. When you call to them, they will not answer you.
28Therefore, declare to them, “This is the nation that would not listen to the Lord their God and would not accept discipline. Truth has perished ​– ​it has disappeared from their mouths.
29Cut off the hair of your sacred vow and throw it away. Raise up a dirge on the barren heights, for the Lord has rejected and abandoned the generation under his wrath.”
30‘For the Judeans have done what is evil in my sight.’ This is the Lord’s declaration. ‘They have set up their abhorrent things in the house that bears my name in order to defile it.
31They have built the high places of Topheth in Ben Hinnom Valley in order to burn their sons and daughters in the fire, a thing I did not command; I never entertained the thought.

32‘Therefore, look, the days are coming’ ​– ​the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘when this place will no longer be called Topheth and Ben Hinnom Valley, but Slaughter Valley. Topheth will become a cemetery, because there will be no other burial place.
33The corpses of these people will become food for the birds of the sky and for the wild animals of the land, with no one to scare them away.
34I will remove from the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem the sound of joy and gladness and the voices of the groom and the bride, for the land will become a desolate waste.

1‘At that time’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘the bones of the kings of Judah, the bones of her officials, the bones of the priests, the bones of the prophets, and the bones of the residents of Jerusalem will be brought out of their graves.

2They will be exposed to the sun, the moon, and all the stars in the sky, which they have loved, served, followed, consulted, and worshipped. Their bones will not be collected and buried but will become like manure on the soil’s surface.
3Death will be chosen over life by all the survivors of this evil family, those who remain wherever I have banished them.’ This is the declaration of the Lord of Armies.
4‘You are to say to them: This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Do people fall and not get up again?
If they turn away, do they not return?

poem.verse: 5Why have these people turned away?

poetryblock.poem: Why is Jerusalem always turning away?
They take hold of deceit;
they refuse to return.

poem.verse: 6I have paid careful attention.

poetryblock.poem: They do not speak what is right.
No one regrets his evil,
asking, “What have I done? ”
Everyone has stayed his course
like a horse rushing into battle.

poem.verse: 7Even storks in the sky

poetryblock.poem: know their seasons.
Turtledoves, swallows, and cranes
are aware of their migration,
but my people do not know
the requirements of the Lord.

poem.verse: 8‘How can you claim, “We are wise;

poetryblock.poem: the law of the Lord is with us”?
In fact, the lying pen of scribes
has produced falsehood.

poem.verse: 9The wise will be put to shame;

poetryblock.poem: they will be dismayed and snared.
They have rejected the word of the Lord,
so what wisdom do they really have?

poem.verse: 10Therefore, I will give their wives to other men,

poetryblock.poem: their fields to new occupants,
for from the least to the greatest,
everyone is making profit dishonestly.
From prophet to priest,
everyone deals falsely.

poem.verse: 11They have treated the brokenness

poetryblock.poem: of my dear people superficially,
claiming, “Peace, peace,”
when there is no peace.

poem.verse: 12Were they ashamed when they acted so detestably?

poetryblock.poem: They weren’t at all ashamed.
They can no longer feel humiliation.
Therefore, they will fall among the fallen.
When I punish them, they will collapse,’
says the Lord.

poem.verse: 13‘I will gather them and bring them to an end.’

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
‘There will be no grapes on the vine,
no figs on the fig tree,
and even the leaf will wither.
Whatever I have given them will be lost to them.’

poem.verse: 14Why are we just sitting here?

poetryblock.poem: Gather together; let’s enter the fortified cities
and perish there,
for the Lord our God has destroyed us.
He has given us poisoned water to drink,
because we have sinned against the Lord.

poem.verse: 15We hoped for peace, but there was nothing good;

poetryblock.poem: for a time of healing, but there was only terror.

poem.verse: 16From Dan, the snorting of horses is heard.

poetryblock.poem: At the sound of the neighing of mighty steeds,
the whole land quakes.
They come to devour the land and everything in it,
the city and all its residents.

poem.verse: 17Indeed, I am about to send snakes among you,

poetryblock.poem: poisonous vipers that cannot be charmed.
They will bite you.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 18My joy has flown away;

poetryblock.poem: grief has settled on me.
My heart is sick.

poem.verse: 19Listen ​– ​the cry of my dear people

poetryblock.poem: from a faraway land,
‘Is the Lord no longer in Zion,
her King not within her? ’
Why have they angered me
with their carved images,
with their worthless foreign idols?

poem.verse: 20Harvest has passed, summer has ended,

poetryblock.poem: but we have not been saved.

poem.verse: 21I am broken by the brokenness

poetryblock.poem: of my dear people.
I mourn; horror has taken hold of me.

poem.verse: 22Is there no balm in Gilead?

poetryblock.poem: Is there no physician there?
So why has the healing of my dear people
not come about?

poem.verse: 1If my head were a flowing spring,

poetryblock.poem: my eyes a fountain of tears,
I would weep day and night
over the slain of my dear people.

poem.verse: 2If only I had a traveller’s lodging place

poetryblock.poem: in the wilderness,
I would abandon my people
and depart from them,
for they are all adulterers,
a solemn assembly of treacherous people.

poem.verse: 3They bent their tongues like their bows;

poetryblock.poem: lies and not faithfulness prevail in the land,
for they proceed from one evil to another,
and they do not take me into account.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 4Everyone has to be on guard against his friend.

poetryblock.poem: Don’t trust any brother,
for every brother will certainly deceive,
and every friend spread slander.

poem.verse: 5Each one betrays his friend;

poetryblock.poem: no one tells the truth.
They have taught their tongues to speak lies;
they wear themselves out doing wrong.

poem.verse: 6You live in a world of deception.

poetryblock.poem: In their deception they refuse to know me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

p.verse: 7Therefore, this is what the Lord of Armies says:

poetryblock.poem: I am about to refine them and test them,
for what else can I do
because of my dear people?

poem.verse: 8Their tongues are deadly arrows –

poetryblock.poem: they speak deception.
With his mouth
one speaks peaceably with his friend,
but inwardly he sets up an ambush.

poem.verse: 9Should I not punish them for these things?

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
Should I not avenge myself
on such a nation as this?

poem.verse: 10I will raise weeping and a lament

poetryblock.poem: over the mountains,
a dirge over the wilderness grazing land,
for they have been so scorched
that no one passes through.
The sound of cattle is no longer heard.
From the birds of the sky to the animals,
everything has fled ​– ​they have gone away.

poem.verse: 11I will make Jerusalem a heap of rubble,

poetryblock.poem: a jackals’ den.
I will make the cities of Judah a desolation,
an uninhabited place.

p.verse: 12Who is the person wise enough to understand this? Who has the Lord spoken to, that he may explain it? Why is the land destroyed and scorched like a wilderness, so that no one can pass through?
13The Lord said, ‘It is because they abandoned my instruction, which I set before them, and did not obey my voice or walk according to it.
14Instead, they followed the stubbornness of their hearts and followed the Baals as their ancestors taught them.’
15Therefore, this is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘I am about to feed this people wormwood and give them poisonous water to drink.
16I will scatter them among the nations that they and their ancestors have not known. I will send a sword after them until I have finished them off.’
17This is what the Lord of Armies says:

poetryblock.poem: Consider, and summon the women who mourn;
send for the skilful women.

poem.verse: 18Let them come quickly to raise a lament over us

poetryblock.poem: so that our eyes may overflow with tears,
our eyelids be soaked with weeping.

poem.verse: 19For a sound of lamentation is heard from Zion:

poetryblock.poem: How devastated we are.
We are greatly ashamed,
for we have abandoned the land;
our dwellings have been torn down.

poem.verse: 20Now hear the word of the Lord, you women.

poetryblock.poem: Pay attention to the words from his mouth.
Teach your daughters a lament
and one another a dirge,

poem.verse: 21for Death has climbed through our windows;

poetryblock.poem: it has entered our fortresses,
cutting off children from the streets,
young men from the squares.

p.verse: 22‘Speak as follows: “This is what the Lord declares: Human corpses will fall like manure on the surface of the field, like newly cut corn after the reaper with no one to gather it.
23‘ “This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: The wise person should not boast in his wisdom;
the strong should not boast in his strength;
the wealthy should not boast in his wealth.

poem.verse: 24But the one who boasts should boast in this:

poetryblock.poem: that he understands and knows me –
that I am the Lord, showing faithful love,
justice, and righteousness on the earth,
for I delight in these things.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

p.verse: 25‘ “Look, the days are coming ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​when I will punish all the circumcised yet uncircumcised:

26Egypt, Judah, Edom, the Ammonites, Moab, and all the inhabitants of the desert who clip the hair on their temples. All these nations are uncircumcised, and the whole house of Israel is uncircumcised in heart.” ’

chapter.head1: False Gods Contrasted with the Creator

p.verse: 1Hear the word that the Lord has spoken to you, house of Israel.
2This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Do not learn the way of the nations
or be terrified by signs in the heavens,
although the nations are terrified by them,

poem.verse: 3for the customs of the peoples are worthless.

poetryblock.poem: Someone cuts down a tree from the forest;
it is worked by the hands of a craftsman with a chisel.

poem.verse: 4He decorates it with silver and gold.

poetryblock.poem: It is fastened with hammer and nails,
so it won’t totter.

poem.verse: 5Like scarecrows in a cucumber patch,

poetryblock.poem: their idols cannot speak.
They must be carried because they cannot walk.
Do not fear them, for they can do no harm –
and they cannot do any good.

poem.verse: 6Lord, there is no one like you.

poetryblock.poem: You are great;
your name is great in power.

poem.verse: 7Who should not fear you,

poetryblock.poem: King of the nations?
It is what you deserve.
For among all the wise people of the nations
and among all their kingdoms,
there is no one like you.

poem.verse: 8They are both stupid and foolish,

poetryblock.poem: instructed by worthless idols
made of wood!

poem.verse: 9Beaten silver is brought from Tarshish

poetryblock.poem: and gold from Uphaz.
The work of a craftsman
and of a goldsmith’s hands
is clothed in blue and purple,
all the work of skilled craftsmen.

poem.verse: 10But the Lord is the true God;

poetryblock.poem: he is the living God and eternal King.
The earth quakes at his wrath,
and the nations cannot endure his fury.

p.verse: 11You are to say this to them: ‘The gods that did not make the heavens and the earth will perish from the earth and from under these heavens.’

poem.verse: 12He made the earth by his power,

poetryblock.poem: established the world by his wisdom,
and spread out the heavens by his understanding.

poem.verse: 13When he thunders,

poetryblock.poem: the waters in the heavens are in turmoil,
and he causes the clouds to rise
from the ends of the earth.
He makes lightning for the rain
and brings the wind from his storehouses.

poem.verse: 14Everyone is stupid and ignorant.

poetryblock.poem: Every goldsmith is put to shame
by his carved image,
for his cast images are a lie;
there is no breath in them.

poem.verse: 15They are worthless, a work to be mocked.

poetryblock.poem: At the time of their punishment
they will be destroyed.

poem.verse: 16Jacob’s Portion is not like these,

poetryblock.poem: because he is the one who formed all things.
Israel is the tribe of his inheritance;
the Lord of Armies is his name.

poem.verse: 17Gather up your belongings from the ground,

poetryblock.poem: you who live under siege.

p.verse: 18For this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Look, I am flinging away
the land’s residents at this time
and bringing them such distress
that they will feel it.

poem.verse: 19Woe to me because of my brokenness –

poetryblock.poem: I am severely wounded!
I exclaimed, ‘This is my intense suffering,
but I must bear it.’

poem.verse: 20My tent is destroyed;

poetryblock.poem: all my tent cords are snapped.
My sons have departed from me and are no more.
I have no one to pitch my tent again
or to hang up my curtains.

poem.verse: 21For the shepherds are stupid:

poetryblock.poem: They don’t seek the Lord.
Therefore they have not prospered,
and their whole flock is scattered.

poem.verse: 22Listen! A noise ​– ​it is coming –

poetryblock.poem: a great commotion from the land to the north.
The cities of Judah will be made desolate,
a jackals’ den.

poem.verse: 23I know, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: that a person’s way of life is not his own;
no one who walks determines his own steps.

poem.verse: 24Discipline me, Lord, but with justice –

poetryblock.poem: not in your anger,
or you will reduce me to nothing.

poem.verse: 25Pour out your wrath on the nations

poetryblock.poem: that don’t recognise you
and on the families
that don’t call on your name,
for they have consumed Jacob;
they have consumed him and finished him off
and made his homeland desolate.

p.verse: 1This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
2‘Listen to the words of this covenant and tell them to the men of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem.
3Tell them, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: ‘Let a curse be on the man who does not obey the words of this covenant,

4which I commanded your ancestors when I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of the iron furnace.’ I declared, ‘Obey me, and do everything that I command you, and you will be my people, and I will be your God,’
5in order to establish the oath I swore to your ancestors, to give them a land flowing with milk and honey, as it is today.” ’
6The Lord said to me, ‘Proclaim all these words in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem: “Obey the words of this covenant and carry them out.”
7For I strongly warned your ancestors when I brought them out of the land of Egypt until today, warning them time and time again, “Obey me.”

8Yet they would not obey or pay attention; each one followed the stubbornness of his evil heart. So I brought on them all the curses of this covenant, because they had not done what I commanded them to do.’
9The Lord said to me, ‘A conspiracy has been discovered among the men of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem.

10They have returned to the iniquities of their ancestors who refused to obey my words and have followed other gods to worship them. The house of Israel and the house of Judah broke my covenant which I made with their ancestors.
11‘Therefore, this is what the Lord says: I am about to bring on them disaster that they cannot escape. They will cry out to me, but I will not hear them.
12Then the cities of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem will go and cry out to the gods they have been burning incense to, but they certainly will not save them in their time of disaster.
13Your gods are indeed as numerous as your cities, Judah, and the altars you have set up to Shame ​– ​altars to burn incense to Baal ​– ​as numerous as the streets of Jerusalem.
14‘As for you, do not pray for these people. Do not raise up a cry or a prayer on their behalf, for I will not be listening when they call out to me at the time of their disaster.

poem.verse: 15What right does my beloved have

poetryblock.poem: to be in my house,
having carried out so many evil schemes?
Can holy meat prevent your disaster
so that you can celebrate?

poem.verse: 16The Lord named you

poetryblock.poem: a flourishing olive tree,
beautiful with well-formed fruit.
He has set fire to it,
and its branches are consumed
with the sound of a mighty tumult.

p.verse: 17‘The Lord of Armies who planted you has decreed disaster against you, because of the disaster the house of Israel and the house of Judah brought on themselves when they angered me by burning incense to Baal.’

poem.verse: 18The Lord informed me, so I knew.

poetryblock.poem: Then you helped me to see their deeds,

poem.verse: 19for I was like a docile lamb led to slaughter.

poetryblock.poem: I didn’t know that they had devised plots against me:
‘Let’s destroy the tree with its fruit;
let’s cut him off from the land of the living
so that his name will no longer be remembered.’

poem.verse: 20But, Lord of Armies, who judges righteously,

poetryblock.poem: who tests heart and mind,
let me see your vengeance on them,
for I have presented my case to you.

p.verse: 21Therefore, here is what the Lord says concerning the people of Anathoth who intend to take your life. They warn, ‘Do not prophesy in the name of the Lord, or you will certainly die at our hand.’
22Therefore, this is what the Lord of Armies says: ‘I am about to punish them. The young men will die by the sword; their sons and daughters will die by famine.
23They will have no remnant, for I will bring disaster on the people of Anathoth in the year of their punishment.’

poem.verse: 1You will be righteous, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: even if I bring a case against you.
Yet I wish to contend with you:
Why does the way of the wicked prosper?
Why do all the treacherous live at ease?

poem.verse: 2You planted them, and they have taken root.

poetryblock.poem: They have grown and produced fruit.
You are ever on their lips,
but far from their conscience.

poem.verse: 3As for you, Lord, you know me; you see me.

poetryblock.poem: You test whether my heart is with you.
Drag the wicked away like sheep to slaughter
and set them apart for the day of killing.

poem.verse: 4How long will the land mourn

poetryblock.poem: and the grass of every field wither?
Because of the evil of its residents,
animals and birds have been swept away,
for the people have said,
‘He cannot see what our end will be.’

poem.verse: 5If you have raced with runners

poetryblock.poem: and they have worn you out,
how can you compete with horses?
If you stumble in a peaceful land,
what will you do in the thickets of the Jordan?

poem.verse: 6Even your brothers ​– ​your own father’s family –

poetryblock.poem: even they were treacherous to you;
even they have cried out loudly after you.
Do not have confidence in them,
though they speak well of you.

poem.verse: 7I have abandoned my house;

poetryblock.poem: I have deserted my inheritance.
I have handed the love of my life
over to her enemies.

poem.verse: 8My inheritance has behaved towards me

poetryblock.poem: like a lion in the forest.
She has roared against me.
Therefore, I hate her.

poem.verse: 9Is my inheritance like a hyena to me?

poetryblock.poem: Are birds of prey circling her?
Go, gather all the wild animals;
bring them to devour her.

poem.verse: 10Many shepherds have destroyed my vineyard;

poetryblock.poem: they have trampled my plot of land.
They have turned my desirable plot
into a desolate wasteland.

poem.verse: 11They have made it a desolation.

poetryblock.poem: It mourns, desolate, before me.
All the land is desolate,
but no one takes it to heart.

poem.verse: 12Over all the barren heights in the wilderness

poetryblock.poem: the destroyers have come,
for the Lord has a sword that devours
from one end of the earth to the other.
No one has peace.

poem.verse: 13They have sown wheat but harvested thorns.

poetryblock.poem: They have exhausted themselves but have no profit.
Be put to shame by your harvests
because of the Lord’s burning anger.

p.verse: 14This is what the Lord says: ‘Concerning all my evil neighbours who attack the inheritance that I bequeathed to my people, Israel, I am about to uproot them from their land, and I will uproot the house of Judah from them.
15After I have uprooted them, I will once again have compassion on them and return each one to his inheritance and to his land.
16If they will diligently learn the ways of my people ​– ​to swear by my name, “As the Lord lives,” just as they taught my people to swear by Baal ​– ​they will be built up among my people.
17However, if they will not obey, then I will uproot and destroy that nation.’
1This is what the Lord said to me: ‘Go and buy yourself a linen undergarment and put it on. But do not put it in water.’
2So I bought underwear as the Lord instructed me and put it on.
3Then the word of the Lord came to me a second time:
4‘Take the underwear that you bought and are wearing, and go at once to the Euphrates and hide it in a rocky crevice.’
5So I went and hid it by the Euphrates, as the Lord commanded me.
6A long time later the Lord said to me, ‘Go at once to the Euphrates and get the underwear that I commanded you to hide there.’
7So I went to the Euphrates and dug up the underwear and got it from the place where I had hidden it, but it was ruined ​– ​of no use at all.
8Then the word of the Lord came to me:
9‘This is what the Lord says: Just like this I will ruin the great pride of both Judah and Jerusalem.

10These evil people, who refuse to listen to me, who follow the stubbornness of their own hearts, and who have followed other gods to serve and bow in worship ​– ​they will be like this underwear, of no use at all.

11Just as underwear clings to one’s waist, so I fastened the whole house of Israel and of Judah to me’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘so that they might be my people for my fame, praise, and glory, but they would not obey.
12‘Say this to them: “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Every jar should be filled with wine.” Then they will respond to you, “Don’t we know that every jar should be filled with wine? ”

13And you will say to them, “This is what the Lord says: I am about to fill all who live in this land ​– ​the kings who reign for David on his throne, the priests, the prophets, and all the residents of Jerusalem ​– ​with drunkenness.
14I will smash them against each other, fathers and sons alike ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration. I will allow no mercy, pity, or compassion to keep me from destroying them.” ’

poem.verse: 15Listen and pay attention. Do not be proud,

poetryblock.poem: for the Lord has spoken.

poem.verse: 16Give glory to the Lord your God

poetryblock.poem: before he brings darkness,
before your feet stumble
on the mountains at dusk.
You wait for light,
but he brings darkest gloom
and makes total darkness.

poem.verse: 17But if you will not listen,

poetryblock.poem: my innermost being will weep in secret
because of your pride.
My eyes will overflow with tears,
for the Lord’s flock has been taken captive.

poem.verse: 18Say to the king and the queen mother:

poetryblock.poem: Take a humble seat,
for your glorious crowns
have fallen from your heads.

poem.verse: 19The cities of the Negev are under siege;

poetryblock.poem: no one can help them.
All of Judah has been taken into exile,
taken completely into exile.

poem.verse: 20Look up and see

poetryblock.poem: those coming from the north.
Where is the flock entrusted to you,
the sheep that were your pride?

poem.verse: 21What will you say when he appoints

poetryblock.poem: close friends as leaders over you,
ones you yourself trained?
Won’t labour pains seize you,
as they do a woman in labour?

poem.verse: 22And when you ask yourself,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Why have these things happened to me? ’
it is because of your great guilt
that your skirts have been stripped off,
your body exposed.

poem.verse: 23Can the Cushite change his skin,

poetryblock.poem: or a leopard his spots?
If so, you might be able to do what is good,
you who are instructed in evil.

poem.verse: 24I will scatter you like drifting chaff

poetryblock.poem: before the desert wind.

poem.verse: 25This is your lot,

poetryblock.poem: what I have decreed for you –
this is the Lord’s declaration –
because you have forgotten me
and trusted in lies.

poem.verse: 26I will pull your skirts up over your face

poetryblock.poem: so that your shame might be seen.

poem.verse: 27Your adulteries and your lustful neighing,

poetryblock.poem: your depraved prostitution
on the hills, in the fields –
I have seen your abhorrent acts.
Woe to you, Jerusalem!
You are unclean –
for how long yet?

p.verse: 1This is the word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah concerning the drought:

poem.verse: 2Judah mourns;

poetryblock.poem: her city gates languish.
Her people are on the ground in mourning;
Jerusalem’s cry rises up.

poem.verse: 3Their nobles send their servants for water.

poetryblock.poem: They go to the cisterns;
they find no water;
their containers return empty.
They are ashamed and humiliated;
they cover their heads.

poem.verse: 4The ground is cracked

poetryblock.poem: since no rain has fallen on the land.
The farmers are ashamed;
they cover their heads.

poem.verse: 5Even the doe in the field

poetryblock.poem: gives birth and abandons her fawn
since there is no grass.

poem.verse: 6Wild donkeys stand on the barren heights

poetryblock.poem: panting for air like jackals.
Their eyes fail
because there are no green plants.

poem.verse: 7Though our iniquities testify against us,

poetryblock.poem: Lord, act for your name’s sake.
Indeed, our rebellions are many;
we have sinned against you.

poem.verse: 8Hope of Israel,

poetryblock.poem: its Saviour in time of distress,
why are you like a resident foreigner in the land,
like a traveller stopping only for the night?

poem.verse: 9Why are you like a helpless man,

poetryblock.poem: like a warrior unable to save?
Yet you are among us, Lord,
and we bear your name.
Don’t leave us!

p.verse: 10This is what the Lord says concerning these people:

poetryblock.poem: Truly they love to wander;
they never rest their feet.
So the Lord does not accept them.
Now he will remember their iniquity
and punish their sins.

p.verse: 11Then the Lord said to me, ‘Do not pray for the well-being of these people.
12If they fast, I will not hear their cry of despair. If they offer burnt offering and grain offering, I will not accept them. Rather, I will finish them off by sword, famine, and plague.’
13And I replied, ‘Oh no, Lord God! The prophets are telling them, “You won’t see sword or suffer famine. I will certainly give you lasting peace in this place.” ’

14But the Lord said to me, ‘These prophets are prophesying a lie in my name. I did not send them, nor did I command them or speak to them. They are prophesying to you a false vision, worthless divination, the deceit of their own minds.

15‘Therefore, this is what the Lord says concerning the prophets who prophesy in my name, though I did not send them, and who say, “There will never be sword or famine in this land.” By sword and famine these prophets will meet their end.

16The people they are prophesying to will be thrown into the streets of Jerusalem because of the famine and the sword. There will be no one to bury them ​– ​they, their wives, their sons, and their daughters. I will pour out their own evil on them.’

poem.verse: 17You are to speak this word to them:

poetryblock.poem: Let my eyes overflow with tears;
day and night may they not stop,
for my dearest people
have been destroyed by a crushing blow,
an extremely severe wound.

poem.verse: 18If I go out to the field,

poetryblock.poem: look ​– ​those slain by the sword!
If I enter the city,
look ​– ​those ill from famine!
For both prophet and priest
travel to a land they do not know.

poem.verse: 19Have you completely rejected Judah?

poetryblock.poem: Do you detest Zion?
Why do you strike us
with no hope of healing for us?
We hoped for peace,
but there was nothing good;
for a time of healing,
but there was only terror.

poem.verse: 20We acknowledge our wickedness, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: the iniquity of our ancestors;
indeed, we have sinned against you.

poem.verse: 21For your name’s sake, don’t despise us.

poetryblock.poem: Don’t disdain your glorious throne.
Remember your covenant with us;
do not break it.

poem.verse: 22Can any of the worthless idols of the nations bring rain?

poetryblock.poem: Or can the skies alone give showers?
Are you not the Lord our God?
We therefore put our hope in you,
for you have done all these things.

p.verse: 1Then the Lord said to me, ‘Even if Moses and Samuel should stand before me, my heart would not go out to these people. Send them from my presence, and let them go.
2If they ask you, “Where will we go? ” tell them: This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Those destined for death, to death;
those destined for the sword, to the sword.
Those destined for famine, to famine;
those destined for captivity, to captivity.

p.verse: 3‘I will ordain four kinds of judgement for them’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘the sword to kill, the dogs to drag away, and the birds of the sky and the wild animals of the land to devour and destroy.
4I will make them a horror to all the kingdoms of the earth because of Manasseh son of Hezekiah, the king of Judah, for what he did in Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 5Who will have pity on you, Jerusalem?

poetryblock.poem: Who will show sympathy towards you?
Who will turn aside
to ask about your well-being?

poem.verse: 6You have left me.’

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
‘You have turned your back,
so I have stretched out my hand against you
and destroyed you.
I am tired of showing compassion.

poem.verse: 7I scattered them with a winnowing fork

poetryblock.poem: at the city gates of the land.
I made them childless; I destroyed my people.
They would not turn from their ways.

poem.verse: 8I made their widows more numerous

poetryblock.poem: than the sand of the seas.
I brought a destroyer at noon
against the mother of young men.
I suddenly released on her
agitation and terrors.

poem.verse: 9The mother of seven grew faint;

poetryblock.poem: she breathed her last breath.
Her sun set while it was still day;
she was ashamed and humiliated.
The rest of them I will give over to the sword
in the presence of their enemies.’
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 10Woe is me, my mother,

poetryblock.poem: that you gave birth to me,
a man who incites dispute and conflict
in all the land.
I did not lend or borrow,
yet everyone curses me.

p.verse: 11The Lord said:

poetryblock.poem: Haven’t I set you loose for your own good?
Haven’t I punished you
in a time of trouble,
in a time of distress with the enemy?

poem.verse: 12Can anyone smash iron,

poetryblock.poem: iron from the north, or bronze?

poem.verse: 13I will give up your wealth

poetryblock.poem: and your treasures as plunder,
without cost, for all your sins
in all your borders.

poem.verse: 14Then I will make you serve your enemies

poetryblock.poem: in a land you do not know,
for my anger will kindle a fire
that will burn against you.

poem.verse: 15You know, Lord;

poetryblock.poem: remember me and take note of me.
Avenge me against my persecutors.
In your patience, don’t take me away.
Know that I suffer disgrace for your honour.

poem.verse: 16Your words were found, and I ate them.

poetryblock.poem: Your words became a delight to me
and the joy of my heart,
for I bear your name,
Lord God of Armies.

poem.verse: 17I never sat with the band of revellers,

poetryblock.poem: and I did not celebrate with them.
Because your hand was on me, I sat alone,
for you filled me with indignation.

poem.verse: 18Why has my pain become unending,

poetryblock.poem: my wound incurable,
refusing to be healed?
You truly have become like a mirage to me –
water that is not reliable.

p.verse: 19Therefore, this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: If you return, I will take you back;
you will stand in my presence.
And if you speak noble words,
rather than worthless ones,
you will be my spokesman.
It is they who must return to you;
you must not return to them.

poem.verse: 20Then I will make you a fortified wall of bronze

poetryblock.poem: to this people.
They will fight against you
but will not overcome you,
for I am with you
to save you and rescue you.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 21I will rescue you from the power of evil people

poetryblock.poem: and redeem you from the grasp of the ruthless.

p.verse: 1The word of the Lord came to me:
2‘Do not marry or have sons or daughters in this place.
3For this is what the Lord says concerning sons and daughters born in this place as well as concerning the mothers who bear them and the fathers who father them in this land:

4They will die from deadly diseases. They will not be mourned or buried but will be like manure on the soil’s surface. They will be finished off by sword and famine. Their corpses will become food for the birds of the sky and for the wild animals of the land.

5‘For this is what the Lord says: Don’t enter a house where a mourning feast is taking place. Don’t go to lament or sympathise with them, for I have removed my peace from these people as well as my faithful love and compassion.’ This is the Lord’s declaration.
6‘Both great and small will die in this land without burial. No lament will be made for them, nor will anyone cut himself or shave his head for them.
7Food won’t be provided for the mourner to comfort him because of the dead. A consoling drink won’t be given him for the loss of his father or mother.
8Do not enter the house where feasting is taking place to sit with them to eat and drink.

9For this is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I am about to eliminate from this place, before your very eyes and in your time, the sound of joy and gladness, the voice of the groom and the bride.

chapter.head1: Abandoning the Lord and His Law

p.verse: 10‘When you tell these people all these things, they will say to you, “Why has the Lord declared all this terrible disaster against us? What is our iniquity? What is our sin that we have committed against the Lord our God? ”

11Then you will answer them, “Because your ancestors abandoned me ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​and followed other gods, served them, and bowed in worship to them. Indeed, they abandoned me and did not keep my instruction.
12You did more evil than your ancestors. Look, each one of you was following the stubbornness of his evil heart, not obeying me.
13So I will hurl you from this land into a land that you and your ancestors have not known. There you will worship other gods both day and night, for I will not grant you grace.”
14‘However, look, the days are coming’ ​– ​the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘when it will no longer be said, “As the Lord lives who brought the Israelites from the land of Egypt,”

15but rather, “As the Lord lives who brought the Israelites from the land of the north and from all the other lands where he had banished them.” For I will return them to their land that I gave to their ancestors.

16‘I am about to send for many fishermen’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​‘and they will fish for them. Then I will send for many hunters, and they will hunt them down on every mountain and hill and out of the clefts of the rocks,
17for my gaze takes in all their ways. They are not concealed from me, and their iniquity is not hidden from my sight.
18I will first repay them double for their iniquity and sin because they have polluted my land. They have filled my inheritance with the carcasses of their abhorrent and detestable idols.’

poem.verse: 19Lord, my strength and my stronghold,

poetryblock.poem: my refuge in a time of distress,
the nations will come to you
from the ends of the earth, and they will say,
‘Our ancestors inherited only lies,
worthless idols of no benefit at all.’

poem.verse: 20Can one make gods for himself?

poetryblock.poem: But they are not gods.

poem.verse: 21‘Therefore, I am about to inform them,

poetryblock.poem: and this time I will make them know
my power and my might;
then they will know that my name is the Lord.’

poem.verse: 1The sin of Judah is inscribed

poetryblock.poem: with an iron stylus.
With a diamond point
it is engraved on the tablet of their hearts
and on the horns of their altars,

poem.verse: 2while their children remember their altars

poetryblock.poem: and their Asherah poles, by the green trees
on the high hills –

poem.verse: 3my mountains in the countryside.

poetryblock.poem: I will give up your wealth
and all your treasures as plunder
because of the sin of your high places
in all your borders.

poem.verse: 4You will, on your own, relinquish your inheritance

poetryblock.poem: that I gave you.
I will make you serve your enemies
in a land you do not know,
for you have set my anger on fire;
it will burn for ever.

p.verse: 5This is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Cursed is the person who trusts in mankind.
He makes human flesh his strength,
and his heart turns from the Lord.

poem.verse: 6He will be like a juniper in the Arabah;

poetryblock.poem: he cannot see when good comes
but dwells in the parched places in the wilderness,
in a salt land where no one lives.

poem.verse: 7The person who trusts in the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: whose confidence indeed is the Lord, is blessed.

poem.verse: 8He will be like a tree planted by water:

poetryblock.poem: it sends its roots out towards a stream,
it doesn’t fear when heat comes,
and its foliage remains green.
It will not worry in a year of drought
or cease producing fruit.

poem.verse: 9The heart is more deceitful than anything else,

poetryblock.poem: and incurable ​– ​who can understand it?

poem.verse: 10I, the Lord, examine the mind,

poetryblock.poem: I test the heart
to give to each according to his way,
according to what his actions deserve.

poem.verse: 11He who makes a fortune unjustly

poetryblock.poem: is like a partridge that hatches eggs it didn’t lay.
In the middle of his life
his riches will abandon him,
so in the end he will be a fool.

poem.verse: 12A glorious throne

poetryblock.poem: on high from the beginning
is the place of our sanctuary.

poem.verse: 13Lord, the hope of Israel,

poetryblock.poem: all who abandon you
will be put to shame.
All who turn away from me
will be written in the dirt,
for they have abandoned
the Lord, the fountain of living water.

poem.verse: 14Heal me, Lord, and I will be healed;

poetryblock.poem: save me, and I will be saved,
for you are my praise.

poem.verse: 15Hear how they keep challenging me,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Where is the word of the Lord?
Let it come! ’

poem.verse: 16But I have not run away from being your shepherd,

poetryblock.poem: and I have not longed for the fatal day.
You know my words were spoken in your presence.

poem.verse: 17Don’t become a terror to me.

poetryblock.poem: You are my refuge in the day of disaster.

poem.verse: 18Let my persecutors be put to shame,

poetryblock.poem: but don’t let me be put to shame.
Let them be terrified, but don’t let me be terrified.
Bring on them the day of disaster;
shatter them with total destruction.

p.verse: 19This is what the Lord said to me, ‘Go and stand at the People’s Gate, through which the kings of Judah enter and leave, as well as at all the gates of Jerusalem.
20Announce to them, “Hear the word of the Lord, kings of Judah, all Judah, and all the residents of Jerusalem who enter through these gates.
21This is what the Lord says: Watch yourselves; do not pick up a load and bring it in through Jerusalem’s gates on the Sabbath day.
22Do not carry a load out of your houses on the Sabbath day or do any work, but keep the Sabbath day holy, just as I commanded your ancestors.
23They wouldn’t listen or pay attention but became obstinate, not listening or accepting discipline.
24‘ “However, if you listen to me ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration ​– ​and do not bring loads through the gates of this city on the Sabbath day, but keep the Sabbath day holy and do no work on it,

25kings and princes will enter through the gates of this city. They will sit on the throne of David; they will ride in chariots and on horses with their officials, the men of Judah, and the residents of Jerusalem. This city will be inhabited for ever.

26Then people will come from the cities of Judah and from the area around Jerusalem, from the land of Benjamin and from the Judean foothills, from the hill country and from the Negev, bringing burnt offerings and sacrifices, grain offerings and frankincense, and thanksgiving sacrifices to the house of the Lord.

27But if you do not listen to me to keep the Sabbath day holy by not carrying a load while entering the gates of Jerusalem on the Sabbath day, I will set fire to its gates, and it will consume the citadels of Jerusalem and not be extinguished.” ’
1This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
2‘Go down at once to the potter’s house; there I will reveal my words to you.’
3So I went down to the potter’s house, and there he was, working away at the wheel.
4But the jar that he was making from the clay became flawed in the potter’s hand, so he made it into another jar, as it seemed right for him to do.
5The word of the Lord came to me:
6‘House of Israel, can I not treat you as this potter treats his clay? ’ ​– ​this is the Lord’s declaration. ‘Just like clay in the potter’s hand, so are you in my hand, house of Israel.
7At one moment I might announce concerning a nation or a kingdom that I will uproot, tear down, and destroy it.
8However, if that nation about which I have made the announcement turns from its evil, I will relent concerning the disaster I had planned to do to it.
9At another time I might announce concerning a nation or a kingdom that I will build and plant it.
10However, if it does what is evil in my sight by not listening to me, I will relent concerning the good I had said I would do to it.

11So now, say to the men of Judah and to the residents of Jerusalem, “This is what the Lord says: Look, I am about to bring harm to you and make plans against you. Turn now, each from your evil way, and correct your ways and your deeds.”
12But they will say, “It’s hopeless. We will continue to follow our plans, and each of us will continue to act according to the stubbornness of his evil heart.” ’
13Therefore, this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Ask among the nations,
who has heard things like these?
Virgin Israel has done a most horrible thing.

poem.verse: 14Does the snow of Lebanon ever leave the highland crags?

poetryblock.poem: Or does cold water flowing from a distance ever fail?

poem.verse: 15Yet my people have forgotten me.

poetryblock.poem: They burn incense to worthless idols
that make them stumble in their ways
on the ancient roads,
and make them walk on new paths, not the raised road.

poem.verse: 16They have made their land a horror,

poetryblock.poem: a perpetual object of scorn;
all who pass by it will be appalled
and shake their heads.

poem.verse: 17I will scatter them before the enemy like the east wind.

poetryblock.poem: I will show them my back and not my face
on the day of their calamity.

p.verse: 18Then certain ones said, ‘Come, let’s make plans against Jeremiah, for instruction will never be lost from the priest, or counsel from the wise, or a word from the prophet. Come, let’s denounce him and pay no attention to all his words.’

poem.verse: 19Pay attention to me, Lord.

poetryblock.poem: Hear what my opponents are saying!

poem.verse: 20Should good be repaid with evil?

poetryblock.poem: Yet they have dug a pit for me.
Remember how I stood before you
to speak good on their behalf,
to turn your anger from them.

poem.verse: 21Therefore, hand their children over to famine,

poetryblock.poem: and give them over to the power of the sword.
Let their wives become childless and widowed,
their husbands slain by deadly disease,
their young men struck down by the sword in battle.

poem.verse: 22Let a cry be heard from their houses

poetryblock.poem: when you suddenly bring raiders against them,
for they have dug a pit to capture me
and have hidden snares for my feet.

poem.verse: 23But you, Lord, know

poetryblock.poem: all their deadly plots against me.
Do not wipe out their iniquity;
do not blot out their sin before you.
Let them be forced to stumble before you;
deal with them in the time of your anger.

p.verse: 1This is what the Lord says: ‘Go, buy a potter’s clay jar. Take some of the elders of the people and some of the leading priests
2and go out to Ben Hinnom Valley near the entrance of the Potsherd Gate. Proclaim there the words I speak to you.

3Say, “Hear the word of the Lord, kings of Judah and residents of Jerusalem. This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I am going to bring such a disaster on this place that everyone who hears about it will shudder,

4because they have abandoned me and made this a foreign place. They have burned incense in it to other gods that they, their ancestors, and the kings of Judah have never known. They have filled this place with the blood of the innocent.
5They have built high places to Baal on which to burn their children in the fire as burnt offerings to Baal, something I have never commanded or mentioned; I never entertained the thought.
